ifyes_whichexternal: spring temperature mainly, but also elevation, precipication (they also looked at land cover and other climate variables)
big_problems: The study didn't really look at direct metrics of growth or growing season so not really. They didn't explicitly look at growing season length but did examine spring temp and productivty. I though it was cool that they looked at productivity in spring but also in summer and fall separatelt and were able to find lags that were somewhat explained by elevation and precipiation

study_scale: 3 sites along elevational gradient and 80 individuals
gs_all_metrics_described: no, end of season is not described. My best guess is that end metric is when snow comes back on
gs_metric_used: start to end (I think for SFGCC)
big_problems: no, other than how weird tree ring methods are

study_scale: 10 elevational bands in 3 elevational transects on mountains in the eastern Swiss Alps
growth_metric: stem density; proportion flowering; proportion fruiting
ifyouthink_no_why: they used snowmelt as a proxy for GSL but didn't actually measure or use the full GSL. I think it's more evidence for start of growing season and growth relationship. pretty hard to follow where in their models to find relationship
excellent_study: space for time study (they even merged data across years)
big_problems: no, but I appreciated their ecological slant

study_scale: 1 site in monitoring network inner-alpine Swiss Rhone valley
